{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Year nav topic5|1961|radio|television|music|film}}
The year '''1961 in radio''' involved some significant events.
==Events== *[[KLAC]] sold to [[Metromedia]] *April 1-the [[Zenith Radio]] FM Stereo standard is authorized for US [[FM broadcast band|FM]] stations by the [[FCC]].
==Debuts== *February 11 – [[KSHE]] debuts as a female-oriented rock station in [[St. Louis, Missouri]]. *April 12: [[WALE (defunct)|WLKW]]/990-Providence, Rhode Island signs on as Rhode Island's only 50 kW A.M. station. *June 25: [[WPLM-FM]]/99.1-Plymouth, Massachusetts signs on. *[[KMJM (AM)|KHAK-AM]] and [[KHAK|KHAK-FM]], [[Cedar Rapids, Iowa]], sign on at 1360 AM and 98.1 FM, respectively. Although formatting [[country music]], neither station is exclusively country until some point later in 1960s. *[[WIBC (FM)|WIBC-FM]] in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]] signs on the air. *''Lohman and Barkley'', a radio talk show featuring [[Al Lohman]] and [[Roger Barkley]] begins on [[KLAC]]. Runs on several stations until 1986 * [[WNOR]], an [[Active Rock]] station in the [[Hampton Roads]] area, has its debut. *[[WKFD]]/1370-Wickford, Rhode Island begins broadcasting.
==Births== * February 25 – [[Todd Blackledge]], former [[NFL]] player and [[sports radio]] host * March 4 – [[Tom Churchill]], [[Iowa]]-based radio and television [[weather forecasting|weatherman]], inventor of the [[Digital Weatherman]], a computer automation system. * March 14 – [[Gary Dell'Abate]], radio producer (''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'') * April 26 – [[Anthony Cumia]], American radio personality ([[The Anthony Cumia Show]], formerly of ''[[Opie and Anthony|The Opie and Anthony Show]]'') *September 29 – [[Stephanie Miller]], comedian and radio talk show host (''[[The Stephanie Miller Show]]'') * December 30 – [[Sean Hannity]], American [[talk radio]] host and conservative commentator
[[Category:1961 in radio|1961 in radio]] [[Category:Years in radio]]

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{good article}} {{Infobox civilian attack | title = Scottish soldiers' murdered | partof =[[The Troubles]] | image = Near Squires Hill - geograph.org.uk - 1515444.jpg | image_size = 300px | alt = |caption = Squire's Hill, north [[Belfast]], the area of the murders | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | location = White Brae, [[Belfast|North Belfast]],
[[Northern Ireland]] | target =[[British Army]] personnel | coordinates ={{coord|54|38|6.46|N|5|59|35.9|W|region:GB_type:event|display=inline,title}} | date = 10 March 1971 | time = | timezone = | type = Shooting | fatalities = 3 | injuries = | victim = | perpetrators = [[Provisional IRA]] | weapons = | numparts = | numpart = | dfens = | dfen = | footage = }} The '''three Scottish soldiers' murders''' was an incident that took place in [[Northern Ireland]] during [[the Troubles]]. It happened on 10 March 1971, when the [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] shot dead three unarmed [[British Army]] soldiers of the 1st Battalion, [[Royal Highland Fusiliers]]. Two of the three were teenage brothers; all three were from Scotland. They were murdered off-duty and in civilian clothes, having been lured from a city-centre bar in [[Belfast]], driven to a remote location and shot whilst relieving themselves by the roadside. Three British soldiers had been killed prior to this event; all had been on duty and killed during rioting. The deaths led to public mourning and protests against the Provisional IRA. Pressure to act precipitated a political crisis for the [[Executive Committee of the Privy Council of Northern Ireland|government of Northern Ireland]], which led to the resignation of Northern Ireland Prime Minister [[James Chichester-Clark]]. The British Army raised the minimum age needed to serve in Northern Ireland to 18 in response to this incident. In 2010 a memorial was dedicated to the three soldiers near to where they were killed in north Belfast. ==Events== British troops had been deployed to Northern Ireland in 1969 for [[Operation Banner]] in response to a deteriorating security situation following the [[1969 Northern Ireland riots]]. The British Army had become involved in the disturbances culminating in the [[Falls Curfew]] of July 1970.{{Cite book | last = English | first = Richard | authorlink = Richard English | coauthors = | title = Armed Struggle: The History of the IRA | publisher =Pan Macmillan | year = 2004 | location = London | pages = 136 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=VFPiMw8iLyAC&pg=PA137&dq=%22royal+highland+fusiliers%22+belfast+1971&hl=en&ei=FKBzTdWVCJSYhQeGs_RS&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22royal%20highland%20fusiliers%22%20belfast%201971&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn =978-0-330-49388-8 | accessdate= 6 March 2011 }}{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/othelem/chron/ch70.htm#Jul |title=A Chronology of the Conflict – July 1970|publisher=CAIN Web Service |date= |accessdate=1 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110514133724/http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/othelem/chron/ch70.htm| archivedate= 14 May 2011 | deadurl= no}} The [[Provisional Irish Republican Army]] was created in December 1969 after a split from the [[Official Irish Republican Army]]. After the split, the Provisional IRA planned for an "all-out offensive action against the British occupation".{{Cite book|title=Memoirs of a Revolutionary |last=MacStiofáin|authorlink=Seán Mac Stíofáin |first=Seán |year=1979 | location = [[Daly City]] |publisher=Free Ireland Book Club |pages=146}} Provisional IRA Chief of Staff [[Seán Mac Stíofáin]] decided they would "escalate, escalate and escalate" until the British agreed to go.{{Cite book | last = O'Brien | first = Brendan | authorlink =Brendan O'Brien (Irish journalist) | coauthors = | title = The Long War – The IRA and Sinn Féin | publisher = O'Brien Press | year = 1995 | location = Dublin | pages = 166 | url = | doi = | id = | isbn =0-86278-359-3}} The [[IRA Army Council]] sanctioned offensive operations against the British Army at the beginning of 1971. In this year, [[Robert Curtis (soldier)|Robert Curtis]] was the first British soldier shot and killed by the Provisional IRA, on 6 February 1971,{{Cite book | last = English | first = Richard | authorlink = Richard English | coauthors = | title = Armed Struggle: The History of the IRA | publisher =Pan Macmillan | year = 2004 | location = London | pages = 137 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=VFPiMw8iLyAC&pg=PA137&dq=%22royal+highland+fusiliers%22+belfast+1971&hl=en&ei=FKBzTdWVCJSYhQeGs_RS&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEUQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=%22royal%20highland%20fusiliers%22%20belfast%201971&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn =978-0-330-49388-8 | accessdate= 6 March 2011 }}{{cite book | last = Taylor | first = Peter | authorlink =Peter Taylor (journalist) | title = Provos The IRA & Sinn Féin | publisher = [[Bloomsbury Publishing]] | year = 1997 | location = London | pages = 89–91 | doi = | isbn = 0-7475-3818-2 }} and two more soldiers were killed prior to 10 March.{{cite book | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Lost Lives | publisher = [[Mainstream Publishing]] | year = 2008 | location = Edinburgh | pages = 70–72 | doi = | isbn = 978-1-84018-504-1}} Brothers John and Joseph McCaig from [[Ayr]] and Dougald McCaughey from [[Glasgow]] in Scotland (ages 17, 18 and 23) were [[Private (rank)|privates]] serving with the 1st Battalion, The [[Royal Highland Fusiliers]], stationed at Girdwood barracks in Belfast.{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/sutton/chron/1971.html |title=Malcolm Sutton An Index of Deaths from the Conflict in Ireland|publisher=CAIN Web Service |date= |accessdate=10 March 2011}} The shootings occurred on 10 March 1971 after the three soldiers had been granted an [[Leave (military)|afternoon pass]] which allowed them to leave their base. McCaughey's younger brother was serving in the same unit but was on duty and unable to join them. The three soldiers were off-duty, unarmed and in civilian clothes. They were drinking in "Mooney's", a [[Belfast city centre]] bar in Cornmarket, one of the safer areas of the city for soldiers at this stage in "the Troubles". The three previous shootings that year had occurred in different circumstances, during rioting. One report said that the three Scottish soldiers were enticed into a car by Republican women who promised them a party. The three were taken to the White Brae, Squire's Hill, off the Ligoniel Road in North Belfast. There they were murdered by Provisional IRA members; two were shot in the back of the head and the other in the chest.{{Cite book | last = Geraghty | first = Tony | authorlink=Tony Geraghty | coauthors = | title = The Irish War: the hidden conflict between the IRA and British Intelligence | publisher = Johns Hopkins University Press | year = 2000 | location = Baltimore | pages = 40 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=azR_Rav_OMYC&pg=PA40&dq=%22royal+highland+fusiliers%22+belfast+1971&hl=en&ei=FKBzTdWVCJSYhQeGs_RS&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=%22royal%20highland%20fusiliers%22%20belfast%201971&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn =0-8018-6456-9| accessdate= 6 March 2011 }} {{cite news | title = 'I told them to go out and pull a bird...but the girls led them to killers | author = Maggie Barry | url = http://www.thefreelibrary.com/'I+told+them+to+go+out+and+pull+a+bird..but+the+girls+led+them+to...-a0160298269| newspaper = Daily Mirror | date = 9 March 2007 | accessdate = 6 March 2011 | location=London}} [[File:Scots soldiers.jpg|thumb|right|John McCaig, Dougald McCaughey, and Joseph McCaig, the three killed Scottish soldiers]] The inquest in August 1971 was not able to establish the exact sequence of events. It was established that all three were shot at very close range, probably in a line. All had been drinking, and Joseph was found to be severely [[Alcohol intoxication|intoxicated]]. The jury was told that the three were probably shot whilst relieving themselves beside the road. The [[coroner]] commented: "You may think that this was not only murder, but one of the vilest crimes ever heard of in living memory". The bodies were heaped on top of each other with two [[beer glasses]] lying near to them.{{cite news| title = Northern Ireland: An Appalling Crime| url = http://time-demo.newscred.com/article/27310beedc82ae77b1195f6d554d2ad1.html/edit| newspaper = [[Time Magazine]]| date = | accessdate = 6 March 2011| location = US| archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20110714173955/http://time-demo.newscred.com/article/27310beedc82ae77b1195f6d554d2ad1.html/edit| archive-date = 14 July 2011| dead-url = yes| df = dmy-all}} After failing to return to their barracks by 18:30 the three were listed as [[AWOL]]. Their bodies were found by children at 21:30. ==Aftermath== The day after the killings, British [[Home Secretary]] [[Reginald Maudling]] made a statement in the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]] in which he informed the house that security arrangements for off-duty soldiers were being reviewed and suggested that the aim of the killers was to provoke the security forces into reprisals. He said that: {{quote|The battle now joined against the terrorists will be fought with the utmost vigour and determination. It is a battle against a small minority of armed and ruthless men whose strength lies not so much in their numbers as in their wickedness.{{cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1971/mar/11/british-soldiers-northern-ireland-murder#S5CV0813P0_19710311_HOC_300 |title=BRITISH SOLDIERS, NORTHERN IRELAND (MURDER) HC Deb 11 March 1971 vol 813 cc597-605|publisher=Hansard |date=11 March 1971 |accessdate=1 April 2011}}}} [[File:Belfast, the cenotaph - geograph.org.uk - 611322.jpg|Belfast Cenotaph, focus of the public mourning in Belfast|200px|thumb]] The funerals were held in Scotland with John and Joseph McCaig buried together in Ayr. Their older brother, serving with the [[Royal Marines]] in Singapore, was flown home for the service. That day, 20,000 people attended rallies in Belfast and [[Carrickfergus]]. In Belfast, the [[Belfast Cenotaph|cenotaph]] at the [[Belfast City Hall|City Hall]] was the focus of the mourning with 10,000 people attending including workers from factories in a gathering that stopped the traffic in the city centre. Many wept openly. The Reverend [[Ian Paisley]] led the mourners in laying dozens of wreaths. The crowd observed a two-minute silence and sang a hymn and the [[national anthem]]. The deaths led to a crisis for the [[Executive Committee of the Privy Council of Northern Ireland|government of Northern Ireland]] with calls for increased security measures. Ian Paisley demanded the Stormont Government's resignation, saying "We can no longer tolerate your weakness. You must go before the whole land is deluged with the blood of innocent men and women." On 12 March, 4,000 shipyard workers took to the streets of Belfast to demand [[Operation Demetrius|internment]].{{Cite book | last = Coogan | first = Tim Pat | authorlink=Tim Pat Coogan | coauthors = | title = The troubles: Ireland's ordeal, 1966–1996, and the search for peace | publisher = Palgrave | year = 2002 | location = New York City | pages = 143 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=33sWKhmPl3UC&pg=PA143&lpg=PA143&dq=internment+scottish+soldiers&source=bl&ots=s5FhK23Tfm&sig=dzKm90zQAKWxYOoqKDfXhwEWRyo&hl=en&ei=8K9zTY_UOMiSswagg5GEDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBg#v=onepage&q=internment%20scottish%20soldiers&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn =0-312-29418-2| accessdate= 6 March 2011 }} The [[Northern Ireland]] Prime Minister [[James Chichester-Clark]] flew to London to request more troops, and when the numbers were not what he wanted, he resigned.{{Cite book | last = White | first = Robert William | authorlink= | coauthors = | title = Ruairí Ó Brádaigh: the life and politics of an Irish revolutionary | publisher = Indiana University Press | year = 2006 | location = Bloomington | pages = 166 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=Ukzbp2i3TvgC&pg=PA166&dq=%22royal+highland+fusiliers%22+belfast+1971&hl=en&ei=FKBzTdWVCJSYhQeGs_RS&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=%22royal%20highland%20fusiliers%22%20belfast%201971&f=false | doi = | id = | isbn =0-312-29418-2| accessdate= 6 March 2011 }} On 23 March 1971, [[Brian Faulkner]] was [[Ulster Unionist Party leadership election, 1971|elected Ulster Unionist Party leader]] and was appointed Prime Minister the same day.{{cite book | last = Walker | first = Graham | title = A history of the Ulster Unionist Party| publisher = Manchester University Press | year = 2004 | location = Manchester|pages = 190 | isbn = 0-7190-6108-3}} The [[British Army]] raised the minimum age for serving in [[Northern Ireland]] to 18 in response to the death of 17-year-old John McCaig.{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/othelem/people/accounts/lindsay.htm |title=Extracts from 'Brits Speak Out', compiled by John Lindsay (1998)|publisher=CAIN Web Service|date= |accessdate=1 April 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/commons/1971/mar/11/defence-estimate-1971-72-army-vote-a |title=Defence Estimate. 1971–72 (Army), Vote A House of Commons Debate 11 March 1971 vol 813 cc671-742|publisher=[[Hansard]] |date=11 March 1971 |accessdate=1 April 2011}} No one has been convicted of the killings. The ''[[Daily Mirror]]'' reported in November 2007 that three Provisional IRA men were responsible for the deaths: [[Martin Meehan (Irish republican)|Martin Meehan]] (died 2007)- Meehan was questioned over the killings but was never charged; Patrick McAdorey- McAdorey was shot and killed in August 1971 during a gun battle in the [[Ardoyne]] area of Belfast. He was also suspected of the fatal shooting, hours before his own death, of Private Malcolm Hatton of the [[Green Howards]].{{cite book | last = | first = | authorlink = | title = Lost Lives | publisher = [[Mainstream Publishing]] | year = 2008 |location = Edinburgh | pages = 79–80 | doi = | isbn = 978-1-84018-504-1}}; and a third unnamed man. The case of the three soldiers is one of those being re-examined by the [[Police Service of Northern Ireland]]'s [[Historical Enquiries Team]].{{cite news |title= Cold Case Cops Probing 'Honeytrap Outrage | url =http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-152202590.html | newspaper = Sunday Life| date =1 August 2006 | accessdate = 2 April 2011 | location=Belfast}} ==Memorial== The mother of the two McCaig brothers visited the site of their deaths in May 1972. She expressed a wish to leave a monument to her sons but was advised that it might well be damaged by vandals. She later said that she was touched by the wreaths and flowers that had been left at the spot. In 2010 the [[Royal British Legion]] Oldpark/Cavehill branch in Belfast raised money from the sale of badges to erect a memorial to the men.{{cite news | title = Memorial To Murdered Scottish Soldiers Sought | url = http://www.4ni.co.uk/northern_ireland_news.asp?id=92023 | publisher = 4NI.co.uk| date =30 May 2010 | accessdate = 8 April 2009 | location=Northern Ireland}} On 28 May 2010, a memorial stone was placed at the site of the killings on Squire's Hill by the families and former regimental colleagues of the three soldiers. The next day a 15-foot [[obelisk]] incorporating carved images of the deceased was dedicated to the soldiers at nearby Ballysillan Avenue. A service of remembrance with regimental drums and colours was then held at [[Ballysillan]] leisure centre attended by around 1000 people including [[Lord Mayor of Belfast]] [[Naomi Long]] and [[Belfast North (UK Parliament constituency)|North Belfast]] MP [[Nigel Dodds]].{{cite news | title = Poignant tribute to murdered soldiers| url = http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/local/poignant_tribute_to_murdered_soldiers_1_1847966| newspaper = The Newsletter| date =30 May 2010 | accessdate = 6 March 2011 | location=Northern Ireland}}{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/cgi-bin/AHRC/monuments.pl?id=722 |title=Three Scottish Soldiers Memorial |publisher=CAIN Web Service |date= |accessdate=9 March 2011}} ===Vandalism=== The memorial at White Brae, Ligoniel, that marks the place of the killings has been vandalised several times since 2011.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-14292072|title=Memorial to murdered Scottish soldiers 'vandalised for fifth time'|date=12 December 2012|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}}{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-northern-ireland-27772680|title=Memorial to three Scottish soldiers attacked in north Belfast|date=9 June 2014|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} ==See also== {{Campaignbox Northern Ireland Troubles|state=collapsed}} *[[Chronology of Provisional Irish Republican Army actions (1970-1979)]] *[[Corporals killings]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *{{cite web|url=http://www.rhf.org.uk/Docs/orderofservice.pdf|title=Order of Service for the memorial ceremony|publisher=Royal British Legion|date= |accessdate=1 April 2011}} *{{cite web|url=http://home.btconnect.com/shankillmirror/3jocksmemorial.htm|title=The 3 Jocks Memorial|publisher=Shankill Mirror|date=|accessdate=1 April 2011}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{PIRA}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Scottish Soldiers' Killings}} {{Infobox event | title = 2018 Hawaii false missile alert | image = File:2018 Hawaii missile alert.jpg | caption = A screenshot of the alert | date = {{Start date|2018|1|13}} | venue = | location = [[Hawaii]] | coordinates = | type = [[False alarm]] | reported deaths = | reported injuries = | reported missing = | reported property damage = | arrests = | cause = [[Human error]]
Inadequate safeguards{{cite news|title=Human error, inadequate safeguards blamed in missile alert|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/technology/human-error-inadequate-safeguards-blamed-in-missile-alert/2018/01/30/0719b326-05da-11e8-aa61-f3391373867e_story.html|accessdate=3 February 2018|work=Washington Post|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=30 January 2018}} | accused = | convicted = | charges = | verdict = | convictions = | sentence = }} On January 13, 2018, a false [[ballistic missile]] alert was issued via the [[Emergency Alert System]] and [[Commercial Mobile Alert System]] over television, radio, and cellphones in the [[United States|U.S.]] state of [[Hawaii]]. The alert stated that there was an incoming ballistic missile threat to Hawaii, advised residents to seek shelter, and concluded "This is not a drill". The message was sent at 8:07 a.m. [[Hawaii–Aleutian Time Zone|local time]]. However, no [[Civil defense siren#United States 2|civil defense outdoor warning sirens]] were authorized or sounded by the state. A second message, sent 38 minutes later, described the first as a "false alarm". State officials blamed a miscommunication during a drill at the [[Hawaii Emergency Management Agency]] for the first message. Governor [[David Ige]] publicly apologized for the erroneous alert, which caused panic and disruption throughout the state. The [[Federal Communications Commission]] and the [[Hawaii House of Representatives]] launched investigations into the incident, leading to the resignation of the state's emergency management administrator. ==Background== {{see also|2017–18 North Korea crisis}} {{North_Korean_missile_range.svg}} [[2017–18 North Korea crisis|Escalating tensions]] between [[North Korea]] and the [[United States]], including threats by both countries that they could use [[nuclear weapon]]s against one another, prompted a heightened state of readiness in Hawaii.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/14/world/asia/hawaii-false-alarm-north-korea-nuclear.html|work=The New York Times|title=Hawaii False Alarm Hints at Thin Line Between Mishap and Nuclear War|first=Max|last=Fisher|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}}{{cite news|title=Is Hawaii Prepared for North Korea Nuclear Attack? Island State Just 4,600 Miles From Rogue Nation|work=Newsweek|url=http://www.newsweek.com/how-did-hawaii-ballistic-missile-attack-alert-happen-780843|first=Summer|last=Meza|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://www.macleans.ca/news/world/hawaiis-false-missile-alert-was-a-wake-up-call-for-a-complacent-world/|work=Maclean's|title=Hawaii's false missile alert was a wake-up call for a complacent world|first=Matt|last=Gurney|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} North Korea had conducted several [[intercontinental ballistic missile]] tests over the past year, most recently in November 2017,{{cite news|url=http://6abc.com/hawaii-startled-by-false-alarm-of-imminent-missile-attack/2939992/|agency=ABC 6|title='Primal fear' as people across Hawaii get false alert of missile attack|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} enhancing its strike capabilities.{{cite news|title=Minutes to Live: When the Nuclear Push Alert is Not a Mistake|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018|work=Esquire|first=Garrett|last=Graff|url=http://www.esquire.com/news-politics/a15157970/america-nuclear-bomb-plan/}} It is possible that North Korea has the [[North Korea and weapons of mass destruction|capability to deliver nuclear missiles]] to Hawaii.{{cite news|last1=Kaleem|first1=Jaweed|title=As North Korean threat grows, Hawaii prepares for nuclear attack|url=http://beta.latimes.com/nation/la-na-hawaii-nuke-2017-story.html|accessdate=14 January 2018|work=latimes.com|date=10 November 2017}}{{cite news|url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/904378/World-War-3-North-Korea-Kim-Jong-un-Donald-Trump-Hawaii-nuclear-war-Pyongyang-David-Ige|work=Sunday Express|title=World War 3: Hawaii governor 'calls on Trump' to Confront North Korea to prevent crisis|first=Joseph|last=Carey|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} Hawaii is located roughly {{convert|4,600|miles}} from North Korea, and a missile launched from North Korea would leave perhaps 12 to 15 minutes of warning time.{{cite news|title=After Hawaii false alarm, what is the federal government's responsibility in nuclear attack alerts?|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/after-hawaii-false-alarm-what-is-the-federal-governments-responsibility-in-nuclear-attack-alerts|accessdate=23 January 2018|work=PBS NewsHour|date=18 January 2018}} Hawaii officials had been working for some time to refresh the state's emergency plans in case of a [[nuclear warfare|nuclear attack]] from North Korea.{{cite news|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/36460330/hawaii-schools-not-prepared-to-shelter-children-in-event-of-nuclear-strike|agency=Hawaii News Now|title=Hawaii schools not prepared to shelter children in event of nuclear strike|first=Allyson|last=Blair|date=September 26, 2017|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} An October 2017 email from the [[University of Hawaii]] to students with the subject line "In the event of a nuclear attack",{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/grade-point/wp/2017/10/10/in-the-event-of-a-nuclear-attack-u-hawaiis-curious-email-to-students-and-staff/|work=The Washington Post|title='In the event of a nuclear attack': U-Hawaii's curious email to students and staff|first=Nick|last=Anderson|date=October 10, 2017|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} containing instructions from the [[Hawaii Emergency Management Agency]] on how to react in case of a nuclear attack,{{cite news|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/37260525/after-missile-alert-mistake-uh-students-ran-for-cover-and-hid-in-classrooms|title=After missile alert mistake, UH students ran for cover and hid in classrooms|first=Ashley|last=Nagaoka|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018|agency=Hawaii News Now}} caused controversy; a university spokesman ultimately apologized for "any needless concern it may have caused".{{cite news|url=http://www.newsweek.com/university-hawaii-nuclear-attack-north-korea-681496|first=Julia|last=Glum|work=Newsweek|title=University of Hawaii Students Warned About Possible North Korea Nuclear Attack|date=October 10, 2017|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} Testing of the civil defense warning sirens and attack drills were also conducted in the state on the first business day of the month beginning in December 2017.{{cite news|url=http://www.esubulletin.com/news/esu-professor-vacations-in-hawaii-during-false-ballistic-missile-alert/article_b88fc476-f8c2-11e7-b02c-8bbde84cf598.html|title=ESU Professor vacations in Hawaii during false ballistic missile alert|work=The Bulletin|first=Sarah|last=Spoon|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}{{cite news|title=Hawaii to resume Cold War-era nuclear siren tests amid North Korea threat|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-northkorea-missiles-hawaii/hawaii-to-resume-cold-war-era-nuclear-siren-tests-amid-north-korea-threat-idUSKBN1DS099|agency=Reuters|date=November 27, 2017|accessdate=January 14, 2018}}{{cite news | last = Sullivan | first = Emily | title = Hawaii Initiates A New Monthly Test Of A Nuclear Siren | url = https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2017/12/02/568019908/hawaii-initiates-a-new-monthly-test-of-a-nuclear-siren | work = NPR | date = December 2, 2017 | access-date = January 31, 2018}} On December 1, 2017, a nuclear threat siren was tested in Hawaii for the first time in more than 30 years,{{cite news|url=https://www.mercurynews.com/2017/12/16/hawaii-is-preparing-for-a-north-korean-nuclear-attack-should-the-bay-area-follow-suit/|work=The Mercury News|title=Hawaii is preparing for a North Korean nuclear attack. Should the Bay Area follow suit?|date=January 16, 2017|accessdate=January 30, 2017|first=Casey|last=Tolan}}{{cite news|url=http://13wham.com/news/nation-world/hawaii-officials-mistakenly-warn-of-inbound-missile-01-13-2018-185755873|agency=WHAM 13|title=Officials in Hawaii apologize for 'false alarm' missile warning|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} the first of what state officials said would be monthly drills.{{cite news|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/ballistic-missile-emergency-alert-mistakenly-sent-to-people-in-hawaii_us_5a5a4e73e4b03c41896616a1|agency=HuffPost|title=Ballistic Missile Emergency Alert Mistakenly Sent To People In Hawaii|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} At 11:45 a.m. on January 2, 2018, the state conducted its monthly test of the civil defense outdoor warning siren system including the sounding of a one-minute Attention Alert Signal (Steady Tone) followed by a one-minute Attack Warning Signal (Wailing Tone).{{cite news | last = Web staff | title = First 2018 test of warning siren system to include attack warning sound | url = https://khon2.com/2017/12/29/first-2018-test-of-warning-siren-system-to-include-attack-warning-sound/ | work = KHON 2 | location = Honolulu | date = December 29, 2017 | access-date = January 31, 2018}}{{cite news | last1 = Rapoza | first1 = Richard | last2 = Agbayani | first2 = Arlina | title = Media Advisory: Monthly Siren and Emergency Alert System Test for January 2, 2018 | url = https://governor.hawaii.gov/newsroom/latest-news/media-advisory-monthly-siren-and-emergency-alert-system-test-for-january-2-2018/ | work = Governor Ige newsroom | location = Honolulu | date = December 29, 2017 | access-date = January 31, 2018}} There was no exercise or drill accompanying the test. Prior to January 13, 2018, 26 drills had been conducted.{{cite news | last = Schaefers | first = Allison | title = State agency disputes 'button pusher's' account | url = https://www.staradvertiser.com/2018/02/06/hawaii-news/state-agency-disputes-button-pushers-account/ | newspaper = Star-Advertiser | location = Honolulu | date = February 6, 2018 | access-date = February 6, 2018}} [[Vern Miyagi]], administrator of the Hawaii Emergency Management Agency, explained that state leaders "couldn't ignore these constant threats and missile tests from North Korea" and felt the need to prepare residents for the possibility of an attack. Officials also outlined what would happen if an emergency alert were sent: a [[push notification|push alert]] to [[smartphone]]s and a message interrupting television and radio broadcasts.{{cite news|url=https://www.cnet.com/news/hawaii-missile-alert-false-alarm-emergency-notification/|agency=CNET|title=Hawaii missile alert on smartphones was false alarm|first=Edward|last=Moyer|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} The [[J-Alert]] used in Japan to warn of tsunamis, etc., also uses the push message notifications.[https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/29/world/asia/japan-north-korea-missile-warning.html ''New York Times'' (29 Aug 2017) Japan awakes to a text message: Missile approaching ] Earlier in January 2018, [[U.S. Federal Communications Commission]] chairman [[Ajit Pai]] said the commission planned to vote to overhaul the wireless emergency alert system.{{cite news|agency=Reuters|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-missiles-falsealarm/ballistic-missile-warning-sent-in-error-by-hawaii-authorities-idUSKBN1F20U1|first=Richard|last=Cowan|title=Ballistic missile warning sent in error by Hawaii authorities|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/hawaii-false-missile-alert-fcc-open-probe-mistaken-warning-n837536|title=Hawaii false missile alert: FCC to open probe into mistaken warning|first=Phil|last=McCausland|agency=NBC News|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} The proposed reforms include providing more detailed information in alerts and confining emergency notifications to a more specific geographic area. Pai said he hoped the reforms, which would take effect in late 2019 if approved by the FCC, would lead to greater use of the alert system in local emergency situations and prompt people to take alerts they receive more seriously.{{cite news|url=https://www.recode.net/2018/1/8/16864564/fcc-pai-wireless-emergency-alerts-harvey-wildfire-reform|work=Recode|title=After Hurricane Harvey and the California wildfires, the FCC is aiming to upgrade the country's wireless alert system|first=Tony|last=Romm|date=January 8, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} ==Incident== ===The alert=== The alert was sent at 8:07 a.m. [[Hawaii–Aleutian Standard Time]].{{cite news|title="Ballistic missile threat" warning in Hawaii a false alarm|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/hawaii-ballistic-missile-threat-alert-phones-was-false-alarm-officials-n837511|accessdate=14 January 2018|work=NBC News|date=13 January 2018|language=en}} People in Hawaii reported seeing the alert on their smartphones. Many screenshots of the push alert were shared on social media platforms, such as [[Twitter]].{{cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/01/13/hawaii-cell-phone-users-hit-with-false-alarm-of-a-ballistic-missile-heading-toward-the-island.html|agency=CNBC|title=False alarm sends Hawaii scrambling amid report of a ballistic missile heading toward the island|first=Javier|last=David|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/13/us/hawaii-missile.html|work=The New York Times|title=Alert About Missile Bound for Hawaii Was Sent in Error, Officials Say|first=Johanna|last=Barr|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} The alert read, in all capital letters:{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2018/01/13/hawaiians-get-ballistic-missile-threat-messages/|work=The Washington Post|title=Hawaii officials say 'NO missile threat' amid emergency alerts|first=Amy|last=Wang|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}
BALLISTIC MISSILE THREAT INBOUND TO HAWAII. SEEK IMMEDIATE SHELTER. THIS IS NOT A DRILL.
Local television broadcasts, including a college basketball game between [[Florida Gators men's basketball|Florida]] and [[Ole Miss Rebels men's basketball|Ole Miss]] being shown on [[CBS]] affiliate [[KGMB]] and a [[Premier League]] match between [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] and [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on [[NBC]] affiliate [[KHNL]] (both under the ownership and management of [[Raycom Media]] under the same operational hub), were also interrupted by a similar alert message, broadcast as a [[Civil Danger Warning]].{{cite news|url=https://screengrabber.deadspin.com/hawaiians-watching-morning-sports-treated-to-terrifying-1822055447|work=Deadspin|title=Hawaiians Watching Morning Sports Treated To Terrifying "THIS IS NOT A DRILL" Missile Threat Alert [UPDATES]|first=Timothy|last=Burke|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/ballistic-missile-threat-inbound-not-11847094|work=Mirror|title="Ballistic missile threat inbound... this is not a drill" Panic in Hawaii over phone message sent in error|first=Stephen|last=Jones|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2018/01/13/hawaii-emergency-officials-say-ballistic-missile-threat-alert-was-mistake.html|agency=Fox News|title=Hawaii emergency officials say ballistic missile threat alert was a mistake|first=Kathleen|last=Joyce|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} The alert message on television broadcasts took the form of both an audio message and a scrolling banner. It stated in part:{{cite news|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/hawaii-missile-alert-today-emergency-management-system-incoming-ballistic-missile-warning-error/|agency=CBS News|title=Hawaii emergency officials say alert of ballistic missile threat was mistake|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}
The [[U.S. Pacific Command]] has detected a missile threat to Hawaii. A missile may impact on land or sea within minutes. THIS IS NOT A DRILL. If you are indoors, stay indoors. If you are outdoors, seek immediate shelter in a building. Remain indoors well away from windows. If you are driving, pull safely to the side of the road and seek shelter in a building or lay on the floor. We will announce when the threat has ended. THIS IS NOT A DRILL. Take immediate action measures.
An alert message also interrupted radio broadcasts in the state.{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/hawaii-false-ballistic-missile-threat-interrupts-soccer-game-on-tv-2018-1|work=Business Insider|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018|title=Video shows the horrifying moment when a false ballistic missile threat alert interrupted a soccer game on TV in Hawaii|first=Brennan|last=Weiss}}{{cite news|url=http://abc7.com/what-hawaiians-saw-on-tv-during-missile-scare/2939946/|agency=ABC 7|title=See the warning Hawaiians saw on TV during missile scare|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} In [[Lihue, Hawaii|Lihue]], a resident reported hearing a message on the radio advising of "an incoming missile warning for the islands of Kauai and Hawaii".{{cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/terror-in-paradise-i-braced-for-nuclear-impact-in-hawaii|first=Jon|last=Letman|agency=The Daily Beast|title=Terror in Paradise: I Got the Hawaii Missile Message and Prepared to Die|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} Culpability for the false alert was attributed to an employee at the [[Hawaii Emergency Management Agency]], who officials said was a 10-year agency veteran{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2018/01/15/hawaii-worker-who-pushed-button-reassigned-after-bungled-missile-alert/1033421001/|work=USA Today|title=Hawaii worker who pushed button reassigned after bungled missile alert|first=John|last=Bacon|date=January 15, 2018|accessdate=January 15, 2018}} who had previously exhibited behavior that had troubled coworkers, according to ''[[The Washington Post]]''.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-switch/wp/2018/01/30/heres-what-went-wrong-with-that-hawaii-missile-alert-the-fcc-says/|work=The Washington Post|title=Hawaii's false missile alert sent by troubled worker who thought an attack was imminent, officials say|first1=Mark|last1=Berman|first2=Brian|last2=Fung|date=January 30, 2018|accessdate=January 30, 2018}} [[Vern Miyagi]], then-administrator of HI-EMA, said the alert had been inadvertently triggered by the employee as he was working at the Diamond Head Crater headquarters{{cite news|url=https://www.buzzfeed.com/mbvd/false-alarm-ballistic-missile-threat-hawaii?bftwnews|agency=BuzzFeed News|title=A False Alarm "Ballistic Missile Threat" Message Was Sent To Hawaii Residents|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} during a shift change.{{cite news | last = Schaefers | first = Allison | title = State had no safeguards to prevent nuclear scare, FCC says | url = https://www.staradvertiser.com/2018/01/14/breaking-news/state-had-no-safeguards-to-prevent-nuclear-scare-fcc-says/ | work = Star-Advertiser | location = Honolulu | date = January 14, 2018 | access-date = January 18, 2018}} During the shift change, a supervisor ran an unscheduled drill in which he contacted emergency management workers in the guise of an officer from [[United States Pacific Command|U.S. Pacific Command]], according to state officials.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/30/technology/fcc-hawaii-missile-alert.html|work=The New York Times|date=January 30, 2018|accessdate=January 30, 2018|title=Hawaii Missile Alert Wasn't Accidental, Officials Say, Blaming Worker|first=Cecilia|last=Kang}} The supervisor deviated from the script, officials said, erroneously stating at one point, "This is not a drill," although he reportedly did state before and after the message, "Exercise, exercise, exercise," agency code to indicate a test rather than an actual emergency. Officials said that upon hearing the supervisor's statement, the employee, who had a reported history of having "confused real life events and drills" at least twice before and later attested in a written statement that he believed there was an actual emergency, clicked the button to send out an actual notification on Hawaii's emergency alert interface during what was intended to be a test of the state's ballistic missile preparations computer program{{cite news | last = Wu | first = Nina | title = State issues different image of screen leading to employee's false missile alert | url = https://www.staradvertiser.com/2018/01/16/breaking-news/state-issues-different-image-of-screen-leading-to-employees-false-missile-alert/ | newspaper = Star-Advertiser | location = Honolulu | date = January 16, 2018 | access-date = January 17, 2018}}{{cite web | last = Coldewey | first = Devin | title = Hawaii's emergency alert interface looks straight out of the '90s | url = https://techcrunch.com/2018/01/16/hawaiis-emergency-alert-interface-looks-straight-out-of-the-90s/ | work = [[TechCrunch]] | date = January 16, 2018 | access-date = January 17, 2018}}{{efn|The selection for ''PACOM (CDW) - STATE ONLY'' on the Hawaii emergency alert interface screen is nearby the selections for ''Amber Alert (CAE) Statewide'', ''Tsunami Warning (CEM) STATE ONLY'', ''Landslide - Hana Road Closure'', ''High Surf Warning North Shores'', and other tests.}} and then clicked through a second screen, which had been intended as a safeguard, to confirm.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2018/01/13/hawaiis-scary-false-missile-threat-workers-push-wrong-button-to-blame.html|agency=Fox News|title=Hawaii's scary false missile threat: Worker's push of the 'wrong button' to blame | first1 = Nicole | last1 = Darrah | first2 = Kathleen | last2 = Joyce | date = January 13, 2018 | accessdate = January 13, 2018}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/hawaii-ballistic-missile-threat-alert-phones-was-false-alarm-officials-n837511|agency=NBC News|title=Hawaii 'ballistic missile threat' alert to phones was false alarm, officials say|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}{{efn|Hawaii is the only state in the United States with a pre-programmed Wireless Emergency Alert that can be sent quickly to wireless devices if a ballistic missile is heading toward Hawaii. If the missile is fired from North Korea, the missile would take approximately 20 minutes to reach Hawaii. [[United States Pacific Command|PACOM]] would take less than 5 minutes to make a determination that the missile could impact Hawaii and would then notify the Hawaii Emergency Management Agency (HI-EMA). HI-EMA would issue the Civil Defense Warning (CDW) that an inbound missile could impact Hawaii and that people should Shelter-in-Place: ''Get Inside, Stay Inside, and Stay Tuned''. People in Hawaii would have 12 to 15 minutes before impact. The Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) is not required to be notified for approval to cancel an alert. Signal carriers allow people to block alerts from state and law enforcement agencies, but not those issued by the President. FEMA can send alerts to targeted audiences but has not implemented this as of January 2018. Other states can take as long as 30 minutes to create, enter and distribute a missile alert. As of January 2018, the nationwide system for Wireless Emergency Alerts to mobile devices has never been tested.{{cite news | title = Federal responsibility in nuclear attack alerts is unclear | url = https://www.staradvertiser.com/2018/01/17/breaking-news/federal-responsibility-in-nuclear-attack-alerts-is-unclear/ | work = Star-Advertiser | location = Honolulu | agency = Associated Press | date = January 17, 2018 | access-date = January 18, 2018}}{{cite news | last = Wu | first = Nina | title = State education department addresses missile scare | url = https://www.staradvertiser.com/2018/01/17/breaking-news/state-education-department-addresses-missile-scare/ | newspaper = Star-Advertiser | location = Honolulu | date = January 17, 2018 | access-date = January 18, 2018}}}} An agency spokesman told ''[[The Washington Post]]'' that the employee, prompted to choose between the options "test missile alert" and "missile alert", had selected the latter, initiating the alert sent out across the state.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2018/01/14/hawaii-missile-alert-how-one-employee-pushed-the-wrong-button-and-caused-a-wave-of-panic/|first=Amy|last=Wang|work=The Washington Post|title=Hawaii missile alert: How one employee 'pushed the wrong button' and caused a wave of panic|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} The employee later claimed to the [[Associated Press]] that he had not heard the "exercise" part of the phone call because a co-worker had placed it on speakerphone partway into the message, and as a result, he had been "100 percent sure" the attack was real.{{cite news|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/wireStory/hawaii-man-devastated-sending-missile-alert-52809261|title=Hawaii man says he's devastated about sending missile alert|agency=ABC News|date=February 2, 2018|accessdate=February 2, 2018|first=Jennifer|last=Sinco Kelleher}} State officials said five other workers were present at the agency at the time and all of them recognized the phone call as an impromptu drill.{{cite news|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/37496908/recap-whats-happened-in-the-month-since-the-false-missile-alert|agency=Hawaii News Now|title=It's been a month since Hawaii's false missile alert. Here's what's changed|first=Olivia|last=Peterkin|date=February 13, 2018|accessdate=February 14, 2018}} ===State response=== By 8:10 a.m. HST, officials later said, [[Hawaii National Guard]] Adjutant General [[Arthur J. Logan|Arthur "Joe" Logan]] had contacted [[United States Pacific Command|U.S. Pacific Command]] and confirmed there had been no missile launch. At that time, the [[Honolulu Police Department]] was notified that the alert had been a false alarm. Officials used the State Warning Point system at 8:13 a.m. to cancel the alert, preventing it from being sent out to any phones that had not already received it, such as those that were switched off or did not have reception.{{cite news|url=http://www.kitv.com/story/37260689/hawaii-emergency-officials-release-timeline-of-false-ballistic-missile-alert|title=Hawaii emergency officials release timeline of false ballistic missile alert|agency=KITV 4|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} The employee who originally sent out the erroneous notification did not respond when directed to cancel the alert, according to state officials. He later said he felt like he had been dealt a "body blow" upon realizing the supposed attack had been a drill, the [[Associated Press]] reported. Another unidentified worker grabbed the employee's computer mouse and cancelled the alert when the first employeee failed to respond. Official messages refuting the emergency alert were not sent out until 8:20 a.m., according to the timeline released by officials after the incident. [[Hawaii Emergency Management Agency]] accounts on [[Facebook]] and [[Twitter]] posted messages at that time urging people to disregard the erroneous alert. Minutes later, Governor [[David Ige]] retweeted the HI-EMA message on Twitter and posted a similar message on Facebook to notify followers that the alert had been canceled. Ige later said the delay was caused in part by the fact he did not know his Twitter login information.{{cite news|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/2018/01/22/breaking-news/after-false-missile-alarm-ige-couldnt-log-on-to-twitter/|work=Honolulu Star-Advertiser|title=After false missile alarm, Ige couldn't log on to Twitter|date=January 22, 2018|accessdate=January 30, 2018|first=Kevin|last=Dayton}} An email from the state was also sent at about 8:25 a.m. advising that the initial alert was not correct, the ''[[Honolulu Star-Advertiser]]'' reported.{{cite news|title='Wrong button' sends out false missile alert|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/2018/01/13/breaking-news/emergency-officials-mistakenly-send-out-missile-threat-alert/|work=Honolulu Star-Advertiser|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} Electronic highway signs were also used to spread the word that the alert had been issued "in error" and that there was no threat to Hawaii.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2018/01/14/hawaiis-false-missile-threat-worker-feels-terrible-after-pushing-wrong-button.html|agency=Fox News|title=Hawaii's false missile threat: Worker 'feels terrible' after pushing the wrong button|first1=Nicole|last1=Darrah|first2=Kathleen|last2=Joyce|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} ====Second alert==== At 8:45 a.m. HST, 38 minutes after the initial alert was sent to smartphones in Hawaii, a second emergency alert was sent, which stated:{{cite news|url=http://thehill.com/policy/defense/368902-nearly-40-minutes-elapse-between-hawaii-missile-report-and-false-alarm|work=The Hill|first=John|last=Bowden|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018|title=38 minutes elapse between Hawaii missile alert and false alarm announcement}}
There is no missile threat or danger to the State of Hawaii. Repeat. False Alarm.
The second alert was sent "well after everyone from Hawaii's congressional delegation to the U.S. Pacific Command had assured the world on Twitter that it was a false alarm", ''[[American City Business Journals|Pacific Business News]]'' remarked.{{cite news|title=Hawaii officials take 38 minutes to cancel false incoming ballistic alert|work=Pacific Business News|first=Janis|last=Magin|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018|url=https://www.bizjournals.com/pacific/news/2018/01/13/hawaii-officials-take-38-minutes-to-cancel-false.html}} Governor [[David Ige]] explained at a news conference that afternoon that officials "had to initiate a manual process" and obtain authorization from the [[Federal Emergency Management Agency]] in order to send the second alert, because there was no automated way to countermand the first alert. Those procedures accounted for the delay more than 30 minutes after officials had confirmed internally that the alert was inaccurate, according to officials. ===Impact=== During the 38 minutes between the first and second alerts, Hawaii's siren warning system — which had been tested as part of a missile preparedness exercise the previous month for the first time since the [[Cold War]]{{cite news|url=https://www.pbs.org/newshour/nation/hawaii-sounds-first-nuclear-warning-siren-since-cold-war|agency=PBS NewsHour|title=Hawaii sounds first nuclear warning siren since Cold War|first=Kamala|last=Kelkar|date=December 2, 2017|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} — was not formally activated.{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/today/index.ssf/2018/01/hawaii_officials_mistakenly_wa.html|work=The Oregonian|title=Hawaii officials mistakenly warn islanders of inbound missile|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} Had a missile truly been launched, the Hawaii push alert should have been followed up with another set of alarms with sirens, which did not happen, as observed by some residents.[http://www.msnbc.com/msnbc/watch/breaking-down-the-false-alarm-hawaii-missile-threat-1136479811623 (MSNBC LIVE 1/13/18) Breaking down the false alarm Hawaii missile threat] Nevertheless, officials stated that some sirens did appear to go off in some communities, with some residents reporting sirens activated on Oahu a few minutes after the push notification.{{Cite news|url=http://communikait.com/2018/01/january-13-2018-hawaiis-mistake-missile-alert/|title=January 13, 2018 - Hawaii's Mistake Missile Alert - CommuniKait|date=2018-01-13|work=CommuniKait|access-date=2018-01-17|language=en-US}}{{cite news|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/us-homeland-security-hawaii-arlert/4207278.html|agency=Voice of America News|title=US Homeland Security Chief Vows to Correct Hawaii's Missile Alert System|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}}{{cite news|title=Hawaii missile alert: False alarm warns residents of "ballistic missile threat"|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/hawaii-missile-alert-emergency-management-system-false-ballistic-missile-warning-2018-1-13/|accessdate=22 January 2018|date=13 January 2018|language=en}} Little to no activity was reported at military bases in the state. Some commercial flights were reportedly delayed for a short time, although the [[Hawaii Department of Transportation]] said there were no widespread impacts at the state's airports and harbors.{{cite news|url=http://khon2.com/2018/01/13/missile-threat-text-alert-was-an-error-no-threat-to-hawaii/|agency=KHON 2|title=Missile threat text alert sent in error after employee pushed wrong button|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} Disruptions were reported across the state. ''[[Honolulu Civil Beat]]'' reported that motorists parked inside the [[Interstate H-3]] tunnel on the island of [[Oahu]] for shelter.{{cite news|url=http://www.civilbeat.org/2018/01/false-missile-threat-mistakenly-triggered-as-part-of-internal-drill/|work=Honolulu Civil Beat|title=False Missile Threat Mistakenly Triggered As Part Of Internal Drill|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018|first=Nick|last=Grulbe}} [[Hawaii News Now]] reported that alarms sounded at Aloha Gymfest, an international [[gymnastics]] meet in [[Kailua, Honolulu, Hawaii|Kailua]], sending hundreds of people running for cover.{{cite news|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/37259815/biggest-fright-of-my-life-many-scramble-for-shelter-after-false-alarm-missile-warning|agency=Hawaii News Now|title=Terror. Fear. Alarm. For 38 minutes, Hawaii thought it was under attack|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://kokokahigymnastics.com/index.php?componentName=Teams&scid=92631/|work=Kokokahi Gymnastics Team|title=Kokokahi Gymnastics Team|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} Students at the [[University of Hawaii at Manoa]] reportedly headed for marked fallout shelters on campus but, finding them locked, ended up taking shelter in nearby classrooms instead. Officials at the [[Sony Open in Hawaii|Sony Open]] [[PGA Tour]] golf tournament on Oahu ordered an evacuation of the media center, while staff members sought cover in the kitchen and players' locker room.{{cite news|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-hawaii-missile-alert-20180113-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|title=False alert of missile attack sparks panic in Hawaii|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} Tourists at [[Kualoa Ranch]] in [[Kaneohe, Hawaii|Kaneohe]] were reportedly taken up to a concrete bunker in the mountains by staff and told to shelter in place there.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/13/us/hawaii-missile.html|work=The New York Times|title=Hawaii Panics After Alert About Incoming Missile Is Sent in Error|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} Congresswoman [[Colleen Hanabusa]] later said her husband had been driving on a [[Honolulu]]-area freeway and saw cars speeding at up to {{convert|100|mph}} after the alert was sent out.{{cite news|url=http://www.kitv.com/story/37260419/hanabusa-criticizes-governor-for-delay-in-letting-the-public-know-about-false-alarm|title=Hanabusa criticizes governor for delay in letting the public know about false alarm|agency=KITV 4|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} Many Hawaii residents and visitors sought shelter or rushed through emergency preparations where they were.{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=11974802|work=New Zealand Herald|title=Panic in Hawaii as Civil Defense accidentally issues alert for 'inbound ballistic missile threat'|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2018/01/13/us/hawaii-false-alarm-react/index.html|agency=CNN|title=From paradise to panic: Hawaii residents and vacationers react to the false alarm|first=Dakin|last=Andone|date=January 13, 2017|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} Some discounted the alarm when they realized that they heard no sirens, and that they personally saw no immediate coverage on television or local radio.{{cite news|last1=Wang|first1=Amy B.|last2=Lyte|first2=Brittany|title='Ballistic Missile Threat Inbound to Hawaii,' the alert screamed. It was a false alarm.|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/post-nation/wp/2018/01/13/hawaii-residents-get-ballistic-missile-threat-messages/|accessdate=14 January 2018|work=Washington Post|date=13 January 2018}} Others were in areas where sirens did go off; in addition, some television stations did broadcast the alert. The incident also created a strain on Hawaii's telephone system. Civil Defense offices in Hawaii were inundated with calls from frightened residents asking for advice or more information, the ''[[New Zealand Herald]]'' reported. Many calls to [[9-1-1]] would not go through.{{cite news|url=https://www.eturbonews.com/175118/ballistic-missile-threat-inbound-hawaii-take-immediate-shelter-50-minute-panic-tourists-residents|agency=eTurboNews|title=Ballistic missile threat inbound for Hawaii – take immediate shelter! A 50-minute panic for tourists and residents|first=Juergen|last=Steinmetz|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} Many wireless data services were likewise initially jammed, leaving many unable to access the Internet to confirm whether the alarm was real.{{cite news|title=How Hawaii reacted to false missile alert|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-42675666|accessdate=14 January 2018|work=BBC News|date=2018}} Some residents called friends or family members to say goodbye.{{cite news|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/international/archive/2018/01/pandemonium-and-rage-in-hawaii/550529/|work=The Atlantic|title=Pandemonium and Rage in Hawaii|first=Alia|last=Wong|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} U.S. Defense Secretary [[James Mattis]] reported that the false alert did not appear to have prompted any sort of reaction from the North Korean government.{{cite news|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/national-security/north-korea-didn-t-react-false-hawaii-missile-alert-mattis-n837876|agency=NBC News|title=North Korea didn't react to false Hawaii missile alert, Mattis says|first=Hans|last=Nichols|date=January 15, 2018|accessdate=January 15, 2018}} ==Responses== [[Twitter]] posts and screenshots of text messages shared on social media in the immediate wake of the first alert conveyed confusion, alarm, and fear among those who received the warning.{{cite news|url=https://www.express.co.uk/news/world/904303/Hawaii-ballistic-missile-threat-warning-drill-launch-attack-USA|work=Express|first=Vincent|last=Wood|title=Hawaii False Alert: Chilling ballistic missile warning issued to residents in Error|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}}{{cite news|url=http://ktla.com/2018/01/13/hawaii-issues-missile-warning-in-error-sending-panic-on-social-media/|agency=KTLA 5|title=Hawaii Issues Missile Warning in Error, Sending Panic on Social Media|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018|first=Cindy|last=Von Quednow}}{{cite news|url=https://slate.com/news-and-politics/2018/01/false-emergency-alert-of-incoming-ballistic-missile-attack-rattles-hawaii.html|work=Slate|title=False Emergency Alert of Incoming Ballistic Missile Attack Rattles Hawaii|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018|first=Daniel|last=Politi}} ===Federal officials=== Members of [[Hawaii Congressional delegation|Hawaii's congressional delegation]] also took to Twitter to dispel the false alarm. Congresswoman [[Tulsi Gabbard]] tweeted at 8:19 a.m. HST, about 12 minutes after the initial alert was sent, stating in all capitals that the message was a "false alarm" and that she had confirmed with officials that there was no incoming ballistic missile toward Hawaii. The next day, she told [[CNN]] that the incident highlighted the need for President [[Donald Trump]] to negotiate with [[North Korea]]n leader [[Kim Jong-un]] to resolve nuclear tensions between the [[United States]] and North Korea, and she called for those responsible for the erroneous alert in Hawaii "to be held accountable".{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2018/01/14/politics/tulsi-gabbard-hawaii-cnntv/index.html|agency=CNN|title=Gabbard: 'Unacceptable' false alarm missile warning in Hawaii underscores need for talks with North Korea|first=Eli|last=Watkins|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} Congresswoman [[Colleen Hanabusa]], a [[Hawaii gubernatorial election, 2018|2018 candidate for governor]], tweeted that the "panic and fear created by this false alarm was very dangerous". In further comments, Hanabusa panned the delay between the two emergency alerts, suggesting it should not have taken 38 minutes for the second message to be sent.{{cite news|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/37260017/lawmakers-demand-answers-on-states-response-to-false-missile-threat|agency=Hawaii News Now|title=Lawmakers demand answers on false missile alarm — and state's response|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} Senator [[Mazie Hirono]] tweeted that officials "need to get to the bottom of what happened and make sure it never happens again".{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2018/01/13/politics/hawaii-missile-threat-false-alarm/index.html|agency=CNN|title=Missile threat alert for Hawaii a false alarm|first=Zachary|last=Cohen|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} In his own tweets immediately after the incident, Senator [[Brian Schatz]] repeated that the first alert had been a false alarm. He described the erroneous alert message as "totally inexcusable", adding,
The whole state was terrified. There needs to be tough and quick accountability and a fixed process.
Commander David Benham, a spokesman for [[United States Pacific Command|U.S. Pacific Command]], confirmed to media that there was no imminent missile threat to Hawaii. A spokesman for [[North American Aerospace Defense Command]] (NORAD) stated that "NORAD did not see anything that indicated any sort of threat to Hawaii" and said NORAD and [[United States Northern Command|U.S. Northern Command]] were still verifying what had happened. A [[White House]] official said the alert had been part of "a state exercise" and President Trump was briefed on the situation.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/hawaii-ballistic-missile-not-drill-false-alarm-text-message-tulsi-gabbard-mistake-a8157971.html|title=Hawaii ballistic missile alert latest: 'Whole state terrified' after text message sent by mistake|work=Independent|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} Trump ordered National Security Advisor [[H.R. McMaster]] to take charge of the administration's response to the incident.{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/01/13/hawaii-missile-warning-white-house-339520|agency=Politico|title=White House scrambles after false missile warning in Hawaii|first=Eliana|last=Johnson|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} About the incident, Trump said, "They made a mistake."{{cite news | last = Ruiz | first = Joe | title = Trump on Hawaii false missile alert: 'They made a mistake' | url = https://www.cnn.com/2018/01/14/politics/trump-hawaii-comments/index.html | work = CNN | date = January 14, 2018 | access-date = January 17, 2018}} U.S. Homeland Security Secretary [[Kirstjen Nielsen]] said the incident was "unfortunate" and officials were working to prevent a similar false alert from being issued in the future. Speaking on [[Fox News]] the next day, she said people "can trust government systems" and should pay attention to any alerts they receive from authorities in the future, in spite of the January 13 incident in Hawaii.{{cite news|url=https://www.afp.com/en/news/23/us-official-defends-early-warning-systems-after-hawaii-failure-doc-wj4d66|agency=Agence France Presse|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018|title=US official defends early-warning systems after Hawaii 'failure'}} {{wikinews|United States: State of Hawaii criticized by head of Federal Communications Commission over incoming missile alert mistake}} [[Ajit Pai]], chairman of the [[U.S. Federal Communications Commission]], announced the commission would launch a full investigation into the false alert.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-42677604|agency=BBC News|title=Hawaii alert: False missile alarm sparks panic|date=January 13, 2018|accessdate=January 13, 2018}} He blamed Hawaii's government for not having "reasonable safeguards or process controls in place to prevent the transmission of a false alert",{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/01/14/hawaii-false-alarm-pai-fcc-340438|work=POLITICO|title=Hawaii to blame for false alarm, FCC chief suggests|first=John|last=Hendel|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} later stating that other agencies should "learn from these mistakes". Gabbard stated in an interview after the second emergency alert was sent that the incident was "a taste of the stark reality of what we face here of a potential nuclear strike on Hawaii", referring to the possibility of a [[North Korea]]n attack. She and former Secretary of Defense [[William J. Perry]] both said the false alert highlighted the possibility of an "accidental nuclear war", in which a technical or human error leads to the [[nuclear warfare|use of nuclear weapons]] due to a misunderstanding or misinterpretation. ===State officials=== [[File:Governor David Ige.jpg|thumb|200px|right|David Ige, who served as [[Governor of Hawaii]] at the time of the crisis.]] [[Honolulu]] Mayor [[Kirk Caldwell]] also tweeted that the message had been a false alarm, saying the message had been sent in error, before the second alert was sent out by the [[Hawaii Emergency Management Agency]]. HI-EMA administrator [[Vern Miyagi]] took responsibility for the incident, ultimately resigning over it.{{cite news|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/2018/01/30/breaking-news/ige-to-announce-results-of-false-missile-alert-investigation/|work=Honolulu Star-Advertiser|title=HI-EMA's Miyagi resigns, 'button pusher' fired in aftermath of false missile alert|date=January 30, 2018|accessdate=January 30, 2018}} Miyagi described the initial warning as a "mistake", saying it "should have been caught" before the alert was sent out. HI-EMA officials, including Miyagi, said there was no evidence that the agency's systems had been [[cybercrime|hacked]] to send the false emergency message. Miyagi apologized for the false alert, as did Governor [[David Ige]], who called the incident "unfortunate and regrettable". They said officials would review the state's procedures to prevent it from happening again. Ige said:
I know first-hand how today's false alarm affected all of us here in Hawaii, and I am sorry for the pain and confusion it caused. I, too, am extremely upset about this and am doing everything I can do to immediately improve our emergency management systems, procedures and staffing.
[[Hawaii Senate]] Majority Leader [[J. Kalani English]] said he was "outraged" by the error, which caused unnecessary "panic and pandemonium" throughout the state. [[Hawaii House of Representatives]] Speaker [[Scott K. Saiki]] announced the House would investigate the incident:
This system we have been told to rely upon failed and failed miserably today. I am deeply troubled by this misstep that could have had dire consequences. Measures must be taken to avoid further incidents that caused wholesale alarm and chaos today. Clearly, government agencies are not prepared and lack the capacity to deal with emergency situations. Apparently, the wrong button was pushed and it took over 30 minutes for a correction to be announced. Parents and children panicked during those 30 minutes. The Hawaii House of Representatives will immediately investigate what happened and there be consequences. This cannot happen again.
The deputy adjutant of the [[Hawaii National Guard]] said that notwithstanding the erroneous alert, people should continue to follow instructions and take shelter if another alert is sent in the future. ==Aftermath== ===Investigations=== [[File:U.S. Army Brig. Gen. Bruce E. Oliveira, left, the commander of Hawaii Army National Guard; U.S. Air Force Maj. Gen. Darryll D.M. Wong, the adjutant general of Hawaii, and Indonesian Brig. Gen. AM Putranto 140901-A-VC646-414.jpg|thumb|250px|Former [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] Brig. Gen. Bruce E. Oliveira, left, was tapped by the state of [[Hawaii]] to lead an internal investigation into the incident.]] State officials held a news conference in the afternoon of January 13 to address the incident. State officials placed former [[Hawaii Army National Guard]] commander Bruce E. Oliveira in charge of internally investigating the events that resulted in the false alert being sent out. In his report, published January 30, Oliveira faulted "insufficient management controls, poor computer software design, and human factors" for the incident. Officials did not name the employee responsible for the error. [[Hawaii Emergency Management Agency]] head [[Vern Miyagi]] initially declined to say whether the employee, who he said felt "terrible" about the false alert, would face discipline. An agency spokesman said January 14 the employee had been "temporarily reassigned" to a position that did not allow him access to the emergency warning system, pending the result of the internal investigation.{{cite news|url=http://time.com/5103320/hawaii-missile-test-worker-reassigned/|work=TIME|title=The Person Who Sent Hawaii's False Missile Alert Has Been Reassigned|first=Mahita|last=Gajanan|date=January 15, 2018|accessdate=January 15, 2018}} The employee was ultimately fired on January 26, following findings in Oliveira's investigation regarding his work history and failure to follow directions. A second employee, who was also not identified and whose role in the incident was not disclosed, was suspended without pay. Toby Clairmont, HI-EMA's executive officer, announced January 20 he planned to retire by the end of the year.{{cite news|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/2018/01/22/breaking-news/hi-ema-executive-officer-clairmont-retiring-this-year/|work=Honolulu Star-Advertiser|title=HI-EMA executive officer Clairmont retiring this year|first=Kristen|last=Consillio|date=January 22, 2018|accessdate=February 2, 2018}} The [[Federal Communications Commission]] also announced that it would conduct a full investigation into the incident.{{cite news |last=Shepardson |first=David |date=January 13, 2018 |title=FCC says launching full inquiry into false Hawaii missile alert |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-missiles-falsealarm-fcc/fcc-says-launching-full-inquiry-into-false-hawaii-missile-alert-idUSKBN1F20V8 |publisher=[[Reuters]] |accessdate=January 13, 2018}} On January 25, an FCC official announced that the former employee responsible for sending the false report was refusing to cooperate with the FCC probe of the incident.{{cite news | title = Staffer behind Hawaii false alert isn't cooperating with FCC probe | url = https://www.axios.com/employee-behind-hawaii-alert-isnt-cooperating-with-1516900119-d903360f-26b0-4190-8f22-a6bb81152726.html | agency = [[Axios (website)|Axios]] | date = January 25, 2018 | access-date = January 25, 2018}} The FCC report, released January 30, faulted the state for failing to quickly notify the public and not having safeguards in place sufficient to prevent the error.{{cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2018/01/30/fcc-hawaii-missile-alert-377272|work=Politico|title=FCC: Official who sent false Hawaii missile alert believed it was real|first=Margaret|last=Harding McGill|date=January 30, 2018|accessdate=January 30, 2018}} FCC Chairman [[Ajit Pai]] stated:
Every state and local government that originates alerts needs to learn from these mistakes. Each should make sure they have adequate safeguards in place. … The public needs to be able to trust that when the government issues an alert it is indeed a credible alert.
Miyagi resigned as HI-EMA administrator the same day the state and federal reports were released. Clairmont announced his resignation a day later. ===Other official actions=== Then-administrator [[Vern Miyagi]] said the [[Hawaii Emergency Management Agency]] suspended tests while assessing what had happened following the incident. He also announced the agency immediately changed its procedures to require two people, instead of just one, to send out both test alerts and actual alerts. HI-EMA employees will be "counseled and drilled so this never happens again", Miyagi said January 14. Governor [[David Ige]] announced January 15 that he was appointing Brigadier General Kenneth Hara, Hawaii's deputy adjutant general, to oversee a review of the state's emergency management systems and procedures and implement reforms.{{cite news|url=http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/37270842/in-address-to-state-governor-to-pledge-fixes-to-states-alert-system|agency=Hawaii News Now|title=Ige: False missile alert won't happen again; 'you have my promise'|date=January 15, 2018|accessdate=January 15, 2018}} The agency also moved quickly to implement a cancellation command that officials said can be triggered within seconds of an erroneous alert being sent out, which it reportedly lacked before the January 13 incident. The Hawaii emergency alert interface screen was updated with a ''BMD False Alarm'' selection the same day, addressing a system deficiency that made it difficult for the state to countermand an alert sent in error. HI-EMA reported that some of its employees received death threats after the false alert incident. In a rare public address, Ige called the threats "completely unacceptable" and said he was "ultimately responsible" for the error. Although Governor Ige's office issued on February 27, 2018, a ''Siren and Emergency Alert System Test'' for March 1, 2018,{{cite news | last1 = Rapoza | first1 = Richard | last2 = Agbayani | first2 = Arlina | title = Siren and Emergency Alert System Test March 1, 2018 | url = https://governor.hawaii.gov/newsroom/latest-news/siren-and-emergency-alert-system-test-march-1-2018/ | work = Governor Ige newsroom | location = Honolulu | date = February 27, 2018 | access-date = March 5, 2018}} the state of Hawaii did not test the nuclear warning siren in March and dropped its monthly test of the nuclear warning siren beginning on March 1, 2018.{{cite news | last = Shapiro | first = David | title = Caution in order for nuclear alert plan | url = https://www.staradvertiser.com/2018/03/04/hawaii-news/fl-ash-back/caution-in-order-for-nuclear-alert-plan/ | newspaper = Star-Advertiser | location = Honolulu | date = March 4, 2018 | access-date = March 5, 2018}} In July 2018, the FCC issued a report and order which makes changes to EAS regulations to "improve the integrity, efficacy, and reliability" of the system and "minimize the potential for false alerts." The changes require EAS participants to configure their hardware to "reject Common Alerting Protocol-based alerts that contain an invalid digital signature and legacy (over-the-air)-based alerts whose expiration time falls outside of specific time limits", and report any false alarms to the FCC. The commission also implemented procedures for authorizing voluntarily participation in "live code" tests—public exercises that simulate an actual emergency in order to "promote greater proficiency" in the system by EAS operators and participants. These changes were the result of recommendations from the FCC's report on the Hawaii incident.{{Cite news|url=https://www.theverge.com/2018/7/12/17565810/fcc-emergency-alert-system-test-psa|title=The FCC is changing up the country’s emergency alert system to prevent another Hawaii incident|work=The Verge|access-date=2018-07-13}}{{Cite web|url=https://docs.fcc.gov/public/attachments/DOC-352524A1.pdf|title=FCC PROMOTES EMERGENCY ALERT RELIABILITY|last=|first=|date=July 12, 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|format=PDF|publisher=FCC|dead-url=|access-date=July 13, 2018}}{{Cite web|url=https://docs.fcc.gov/public/attachments/DOC-351865A1.pdf|title=Fact Sheet: Amendment of Part 11 of the Commission’s Rules Regarding the Emergency Alert System|last=|first=|date=June 21, 2018|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|format=PDF|publisher=FCC|dead-url=|access-date=July 13, 2018}} At 8:18 a.m. HST on October 3, 2018, the first national Wireless Emergency Alert (WEA) test, also known as the Presidential Alert text system, was broadcast by FEMA in coordination with the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) through cell phone towers to wireless devices.{{cite news|url=http://www.staradvertiser.com/2018/10/02/breaking-news/emergency-alert-test-going-out-to-mobile-phones-nationwide-wednesday/|title=Emergency alert test goes out to mobile phones nationwide|date=October 2, 2018|newspaper=Star-Advertiser|location=Honolulu|access-date=October 3, 2018}} The subject read, “Presidential Alert” and the text message sent read, “THIS IS A TEST of the National Wireless Emergency Alert System. No action is needed.” Since the WEA test was issued on behalf of the President, no one could opt out.{{cite web|url=https://www.fema.gov/emergency-alert-test|title=The IPAWS National Test|date=October 3, 2018|work=FEMA|access-date=October 3, 2018}} The 8:18 a.m. HST WEA test lasted for 30 minutes and was followed at 8:20 a.m. HST with the fourth nationwide Emergency Alert System (EAS) test which lasted about a minute and involved radio and television broadcasters, cable systems, satellite radio and television providers, and wireline video providers.{{efn|Previous national EAS tests occurred in November 2011, September 2016, and September 2017.}} These two tests were scheduled for September 20, 2018, but the occurrence of [[Hurricane Florence]] caused the two tests to be postponed. Although FEMA called this a national test of [[Integrated Public Alert and Warning System]] (IPAWS), neither the National Weather Service (NWS) nor the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Weather Radios participated in the tests.{{cite web|url=https://www.weather.gov/media/box/FEMA%20WEA.pdf|title=FEMA National WEA/EAS Test|date=October 3, 2018|work=weather.gov|access-date=October 3, 2018}} ===Outside Hawaii=== North Korea's ''[[Rodong Sinmun]]'', the ruling Communist Party newspaper, described the false alarm as a "tragicomedy."{{cite news | title = North Korea mocks Trump, calls Hawaii's false alarm a 'tragicomedy' | url = https://www.staradvertiser.com/2018/01/16/breaking-news/north-korea-scoffs-at-trumps-nuclear-button-tweet/ | work = Star-Advertiser | location = Honolulu | agency = Associated Press and New York Times | date = January 16, 2018 | access-date = January 17, 2018}} An official with the [[Alaska Division of Homeland Security & Emergency Management|Division of Homeland Security & Emergency Management]] in the U.S. state of [[Alaska]], also believed to be within the theoretical range of [[North Korea]]n [[North Korea and weapons of mass destruction|nuclear missiles]], said his department encourages Alaskans to [[shelter in place]] rather than trying to get elsewhere if there is an attack, as many people in Hawaii did after the false alert was issued.{{cite news|url=http://www.ktva.com/story/37261774/alaska-taking-different-tack-from-hawaii-on-missile-alerts|agency=KTVA|title=Alaska taking different tack from Hawaii on missile alerts|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 14, 2018}} U.S. Senator [[Brian Schatz]], one of Hawaii's two members of the [[United States Senate]], introduced federal legislation that would prohibit state and local agencies from notifying the public of a missile launch, placing the responsibility on federal authorities to make that determination.
